title.narrative: SP Nigeria - Strategic Partnership

description.narrative: An inclusive and peaceful Niger delta, based on equity and sustainable development, in which local communties manage their natural resources effectively for sustainable green growth, and where the space for negotiations between communities, government and companies on oil impact and oil management is institutionalized.

The strategic partnership program focuses on 1 topic in Nigeria: Extractives. For decades communities in the Niger Delta suffered the negative consequences of oil and gas exploitation (pollution, insecurity, and loss of livelihood opportunities) while scarcely benefiting from job opportunities or the reinvestment of oil and gas revenue. Combined with corruption, poor governance, and ineffective enforcement of environmental laws, this has led to oil theft, illegal refining, and the international illegal trading of oil. In this context, the launch of the clean-up process (in line with the 2011 UNEP report ) in June 2016 by the Minister of Environment offers new hope and provides opportunities to lobby for the participation of the communities in the zonal and local governance structures that will supervise the implementation of the emergency measures and the clean-up. Lobbying efforts concentrate on the Federal Minister of Environment who is delaying access to funds already approved for the clean-up, and on the Hydrocarbon Pollution Remediation Project (HYPREP) in charge of the clean-up. The program partners advocate for inclusive implementation and organize exchange visits and strategy meetings to mobilize women to engage in the governance structures. A challenge for the cleanup is the negative impact of bunkering and artisanal refining. Community members are willing to start a dialogue with artisanal refiners, they are afraid of doing so due to the risk of violent reprisals. The program lobbies with the relevant security agencies to ensure peace in Ogoniland and the wider Niger Delta. Further advocacy opportunities aimed at including social and human rights aspects in the Environmental Impact Assessments that are obligatory for oil and gas companies

title.narrative: Peace Corporate Indictors
Number of beneficiaries reached (PE)

description.narrative: Number of people who benefitted directly/indirectly through activities implemented or services established/enabled/improved by a Cordaid peace, security and justice project/programme

title.narrative: Peace Thematic Indicators
DD4: Number of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

description.narrative: Counts each occasion that the program partners succeed in engaging with a new lobby target (decision-makers and power holders) on an important advocacy topic.

title.narrative: DD5: Number of CSOs with increased L&A capacities

description.narrative: Increased lobby and advocacy capacity of CSOs. The capacity is evaluated yearly.

title.narrative: DD6: Number of implementing partners in security and justice projects

description.narrative: Number of CSOs directly partnering in the programme interventions.

title.narrative: DD2: Number of laws, policies and norms/attitudes blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development

description.narrative: Number of concrete changes in policies or laws brought about through lobby and advocacy by the program partners.

title.narrative: DD1: Number of laws, policies and norms, implemented for sustainable and inclusive development

description.narrative: Number of concrete changes in policy implementation brought about through lobby and advocacy by the program partners.

title.narrative: DD3: Number of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, and/or influencing the debate

description.narrative: Number of times lobby and advocacy targets (decision-makers and power holders) include CSOs in the decision making process or react upon the issues brought forward by the program partners.

title.narrative: Number of people (disaggregated by gender) reached with awareness raising
Number of consultation processes with communities for policy dialogue with decision-makers
Number of processes for adoption and implementation of policies and legalisation
Number of networks with increased capacities to coordinate joint actions
Perception of civil society actors on civic space (space for engagement of civil society)
Number of communities involved in L&A initiatives
Number of communities reached (SJ)
Number of reports with local evidence reflecting perspectives of target groups made available
Number of campaigns to influence policy dialogue
Peace Project Specific Indicators
F) Communities increase their capacity for advocacy towards decision makers
K) National decision makers initiate policy processes with inclusive civil society engagement
B) CSOs and Cordaid collect local evidence from target groups (with participatory data collection methodologies) for effective lobby and advocacy strategies and knowledge building
C) CSOs and Cordaid increase community awareness on advocacy topics
D) CSOs organize in networks to build collaborate capacity for lobby and advocacy
J) Stakeholders support the role of civil society and assure that the voice of communities and minority groups are heard in policy dialogue
A) Civil society partners (CSOs) and Cordaid increase their capacity to influence and engage in dialogue with policy makers, politicians and companies
E) Communities organize inclusive dialogue in which women, youth and minority groups can voice their needs and concerns
H) Government institutions, private sector and civil society develop structural dialogue and engagement
I) CSOs are influential in international multi-stakeholder alliances and platforms
N) National government institutions, international development actors and multinational companies implement laws and policies favourable to the target communities with transparent practices & systems
(SP) Number of agreements supported by official documents for the adjustment and design of policies and for and policy implementation
(SP) Number of communities involved in data collection and analysis of data for advocacy
(SP) Progress steps made by CSOs to organise data collection
